content:
The "Forage Improvement Act of 1997" includes provisions for the management of grazing on federal lands and miscellaneous regulations. The Act also outlines rules of construction. The "Forage Improvement Act of 1997" does not affect grazing in National Parks, Wildlife Refuges, National Forests managed as National Grasslands, non-Federal lands, or lands held in trust for Indians. It also does not limit hunting, fishing, recreation, or other multiple use activities on Federal lands. The Act does not impact valid existing rights, reservations, agreements. The "Forage Improvement Act of 1997" does not affect grazing in National Parks, Wildlife Refuges, or National Forests managed as National Grasslands. It also does not limit hunting, fishing, or recreation on Federal lands. Section 1323 of Public Law 96-487 continues to apply for access to nonfederally owned lands. The Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Interior aim to coordinate livestock grazing on Federal lands in accordance with existing laws. This title pertains to grazing management on National Forest System lands by the Secretary of Agriculture under various laws including the Organic Administration Act of 1897, the Granger-Thye Act of 1950, the Multiple-Use Sustained-Yield Act of 1960, the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974, and the National Forest Management Act of 1976. The National Forest Management Act of 1976, the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, and the Public Rangelands Improvement Act of 1978 pertain to grazing management on Federal lands administered by the Secretary of the Interior. This includes laws such as the Taylor Grazing Act of 1934, the Oregon and California Railroad and Coos Bay Wagon Road Grant Lands Act of 1937, and the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The title also applies to the management of grazing on certain other United States lands by the Secretary concerned on behalf of another federal department or agency under a memorandum of understanding. SEC. 102. DEFINITIONS. Authorized officer is defined as a person authorized by the Secretary concerned to administer this title, related laws, and regulations. Federal lands refer to lands owned by the United States outside Alaska, included in the National Forest System or administered by the Secretary of the Interior. Grazing permit or lease authorizes the use of Federal lands for grazing livestock within a grazing district. The Taylor Grazing Act and the Granger-Thye Act designate grazing areas on federal lands. A land use plan is a management plan for National Forest units prepared by the Forest Service. The curr_chunk discusses resource management plans for National Forest units and Federal lands administered by the Bureau of Land Management. It defines the National Forest System and the term "Secretary concerned." The term "Secretary concerned" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture for the National Forest System and the Secretary of the Interior for Federal lands under specified laws. The "sixteen contiguous Western States" include Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. SEC. 103. MONITORING. Monitoring of resource conditions and trends on Federal lands within allotments is to be performed by qualified persons from specific groups, including government personnel, grazing permittees, and professional consultants. The monitoring must adhere to regional or state criteria and protocols selected by the Secretary, be site-specific, scientifically valid, and subject to peer review. Data collected must be periodically verified and can also include previously collected information. The Secretary will consider historical data and information that is objective and reliable. Monitoring data must meet specific requirements and will be used to evaluate ecological changes, management actions, and the effectiveness of meeting management objectives on Federal lands. The Secretary will provide notice of monitoring to affected permittees or lessees, with prior notice of at least 48 hours. SEC. 104 prohibits subleasing grazing permits on Federal lands to livestock not owned or controlled by the permit holder. SEC. 105 pertains to cooperative allotment management plans. Written agreements for outcome-based standards may be included in allotment management plans or grazing permits/leases under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act. These agreements replace prescriptive terms with outcome-based standards for managing grazing activities in specific areas. Qualified grazing permittees or lessees who demonstrate sound stewardship may request such agreements to be considered by the Secretary concerned. Written agreements for outcome-based standards can be included in allotment management plans or grazing permits/leases under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act. These agreements replace prescriptive terms with outcome-based standards for managing grazing activities in specific areas. Qualified permittees or lessees who demonstrate sound stewardship may request such agreements to be considered by the Secretary concerned. The agreements must contain performance goals expressed in objective, quantifiable, and measurable terms, establish performance indicators, provide a basis for comparing management results, and describe means for verification and validation of measured values. All applicable laws to allotment management plans and grazing permits/leases must be followed. Activities under this section, including written agreements for outcome-based standards in allotment management plans or grazing permits/leases, are exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. SEC. 106. FEES AND CHARGES. The grazing fee for livestock on Federal lands in the sixteen western States is calculated based on the 12-year average of beef cattle production value and the United States Treasury Securities rate. For foreign-owned grazing permits, the fee is determined differently. The grazing fee for livestock on Federal lands in the sixteen western States is determined based on the average grazing fee charged by the State or on private lands in the same State. An animal unit month is defined as one month's use of range by specific animals. The grazing fee for livestock on Federal lands in the sixteen western States is determined based on the average grazing fee charged by the State or on private lands in the same State. An animal unit month is defined as one month's use of range by specific animals, including sheep, goats, and cattle of certain ages. Livestock less than six months old and progeny of animals on which a grazing fee is paid are not counted as animal unit months. The Economic Research Service of the Department of Agriculture will compile and report the gross value of production of beef cattle on a dollars-per-bred-cow basis for the United States. This information will be used to determine the grazing fee for the following year and will be published in the Federal Register by February 15th annually. The fees and charges under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 must reflect processing costs and be adjusted periodically. Any changes in service charges must be published in the Federal Register. TITLE II--MISCELLANEOUS

SEC. 201. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act and its amendments will take effect on the first day of the initial grazing season after enactment.

SEC. 202. ISSUANCE OF NEW REGULATIONS.

The Secretaries of Agriculture and Interior will coordinate and publish new regulations within 180 days of enactment.
